name: An Agent-Based Model of Indirect Minority Influence on Social Change
description: This model demonstrates how different psychological mechanisms and network structures generate various patterns of cultural dynamics including cultural diversity, polarization, and majority dominance, as explored by Jung, Bramson, Crano, Page, and Miller (2021). It focuses particularly on the psychological mechanisms of indirect minority influence, a concept introduced by Serge Moscovici (1976, 1980)'s genetic model of social influence, and validates how such influence can lead to social change.
releaseNotes: Model for: Jung, J., Bramson, A., Crano, W. D., Page, S. E., & Miller, J. H. (2021). Cultural drift, indirect minority influence, network structure, and their impacts on cultural change and diversity. American Psychologist, 76, 1039--1053.
referencePublication: Jung, J., Bramson, A., Crano, W. D., Page, S. E., & Miller, J. H. (2021). Cultural drift, indirect minority influence, network structure, and their impacts on cultural change and diversity. American Psychologist, 76(6), 1039–1053. https://doi.org/10.1037/amp0000844
